headline: Measuring the on-time performance of ACTransit buses
subhead: The Daily Californian tracked arrival times at AC Transit bus stops nearby campus and compared them to their scheduled arrivals.
author: Seokhyeon Ryu

sections.text: Delays are an inevitable experience when riding the bus. Particularly nearby campus and on Shattuck Ave, there are many long waits for the bus to arrive. The main culprit appears to be traffic, which can come to a standstill on busy hours. The Daily Californian investigated the frequency and period of bus delays at stops surrounding campus. AC Transit publishes a schedule for stops considered “important landmarks along the route,” according to its website. For example, the schedule for 51BBerkeley Amtrak provides times for five stops along that route. However, the majority of stops don’t have departure schedules posted at the stop or online. Instead, AC Transit recommends passengers rely on “real-time” predictions provided by NextBus, a company that partners with transit agencies to provide transit information Their technology tracks buses with GPS and predicts their arrival times at each stop, taking into account historical traffic patterns, according to their website. The prediction service is available on ACTransit’s website and NextBus app. (Some apps, such as Transit, appear to pull their data directly from NextBus.)

Since most stops don’t have a published schedule, in order to measure bus delays, The Daily Californian measured the time difference between when the NextBus service says a bus is 30 minutes from a stop and when it actually arrives (according to the service). 

Let us say you are at the Bancroft Way & Telegraph Ave bus stop.

Each arc represents one bus trip, starting 30 minutes before the bus is scheduled to arrive. In the example above, the arc ends when the bus actually arrived, 12 minutes late. Below, each chart shows a random selection of 100 trips on a given route.

Some routes, such as F San Francisco and 18 Lake Merritt BART, have relatively unpredictable arrivals. Others, such as 51B Berkeley Amtrak and 36 West Oakland BART, are more reliably on time.

Average delay also varies, as F Berkeley experiences close to no delays, on average, while the F San Francisco in the other direction averages several minutes late. More on methodology is explained at the end of this article.

Stops, not just routes, have variation in delay. In the bubble map below, each stop is represented by a circle whose size is proportional to the stop’s average delay (that includes all routes at that stop). Delays are highest along Shattuck southbound and Piedmont southbound. There is also a noticeably large average delay on Bancroft Way and Telegraph Ave.
